text: Mr. Berger, you may proceed whenever you're ready.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
And you say you raised a federal constitutional claim of this sort in the California Court of Appeals?
Yes, sir.
For it, at any rate, to reach a different conclusion than the Supreme Court of California had reached.
--Well, that's true, and for any California court to reach a different conclusion.
In California, I take it they say that you can get a declaration of invalidity and an injunction?
That is what the California courts say.
And an injunction?
Well, that I suppose would go along with the declaration of invalidity.
Well, in any event, what's really left over is whether you can get damages for a temporary taking.
If you get a declaration of invalidity, what's left is compensation for the other period of time, that's correct, Your Honor.
And saying that you can't get damages for a temporary taking is a federal constitutional issue?
Yes, sir.
And just like whether there was a taking in the first place.
It's a question of degree and of degree only.
Well, you don't reach the remedy until you find there's a taking.
In this case the complaint alleged there was a taking.
Well, I know.
Nobody challenged that.
I know, I know.
And the courts only dealt with the question of whether the remedy--
That's right.
--was just compensation.
But there were two constitutional questions and they just, they decided one of them.
No, they assumed one of them.
Well, all right.
But they assumed that the pleading under local law--
Well, I know.
--adequately alleged a taking.
All I'm trying to get at is that we needn't worry that there was no decision below that there was a taking.
I agree with Your Honor that--
That's all I'm trying--
--you need not be concerned because the court below held it to be immaterial.
--May I ask, Mr. Berger--
Yes, sir.
--it seems to me there might be two different sorts of taking, and I'm just curious as to what your allegation.
I believe we do, Your Honor.
That even if the regulation is voided, that the temporary deprivation of use would have been so serious that it amounts to a taking of your property?
--The detailed allegations are not that express in the complaint.
I understand, that that's the taking and if it remains in place it's a taking.
--It seems to me that's implicit in the complaint, Your Honor.
You think it's implicit in all allegations of taking?
It was never questioned in the courts below.
All allegations of taking?
I believe it is, and as nobody ever questioned it--
It certainly is at least theoretically possible that the temporary deprivation would not be serious enough to cross the constitutional threshold?
--Well, in the colorful language of this Court in Loretto, taking doesn't depend on whether it's bigger than a breadbox.
That's a physical occupation.
I understand that that was a physical occupation rather than a regulatory taking.
But you're out of court now, you're out of court now.
But that's a matter of fact.
You're out of court.
The allegations are that the regulation did in fact take the use of property.
And you had no chance to prove it because you're out of court for another reason.
At this point, yes.
And do California rules allow notice pleading, the way the federal rules do?
Technically, it's called fact pleading, but the facts that are required to be pled in the complaint are equivalent to federal notice pleading.
May I ask you about the discussion of temporary taking.
Yes, Your Honor.
So as of today, the argument in this case, are we to consider it as a temporary or a permanent taking?
Well, this temporary taking is now nine years old, and I strongly suspect from an economist's standpoint that if you have taken something for that long you've taken it permanently.
If we leave the ordinance in effect, it'll be a permanent taking so far as we know, is that correct?
Yes, that's correct.
Well now, the case was litigated, though, was it not, under some temporary ordinance, as opposed to the one now in effect?
The case was originally filed under what they called a temporary ordinance, yes, ma'am.
And you assert for our purposes here that that admittedly temporary ordinance is a permanent taking?
That temporary ordinance was in effect for three years, of course, before they replaced it.
But we are looking at it from the standpoint of that original temporary ordinance.
--I think-what this case involves is not the so-called temporary ordinance or the so-called permanent ordinance, but the County's pattern of regulation of this particular piece of land.
Well, that's the record we have in front of us.
That's correct.

Well, under your theory would a municipality or county that made it temporarily impossible to build on something because of road repair or something of that kind have made a taking then that requires compensation for that interim period?
--No, not necessarily, Your Honor.
But possibly?
It would depend on what the facts showed.
Well, some of these things take a while.
Yes, they can.
And in your view that would require compensation.
--Under settled law, Your Honor, if access is totally deprived to property, that is the taking of the property interest and requires compensation.
Even though it is admittedly for a temporary duration?
Yes, ma'am.
May I inquire, do they do this in California, what you've been saying in response to Justice O'Connor, that they routinely pay just compensation in dollars on these road repair situations?
--Not on minor road repairs, Your Honor.
I thought in California the rule was they don't pay dollars for taking.
I'm talking there about direct condemnation.

But supposing they didn't... I think Justice O'Connor's question was supposing they didn't go through the compensation procedure, they just built a road in a way that denied access, all the use of an adjacent parcel of land, for 90 days.
90 days, I suspect--
Well, say six months.
--Yes.
Would he be entitled to compensation in California--
Yes.
--for the same interference caused by road repair?

I think if you looked at a case that the California Supreme Court decided called Jones versus People, which is precisely that case, where a parcel of vacant land was rendered inaccessible because of a freeway--
I'm talking about temporarily, not permanently.
--Well, eventually they did get access, eventually.
For a temporary period?
And the Supreme Court said that damages had to be paid, just compensation had to be paid.
Well, how does that square with Agins?
They view regulations very differently from the way that they view anything else.
So that if the state built a wall around this place because they thought it was too dangerous, the flood and all the rest, then you would have gotten compensation?
I believe if they'd have done that--
But not if they said, we'll post signs that say nobody can enter?
--I believe if they had done that the courts would have viewed it differently.
Mr. Berger, did you argue to the Court of Appeals specifically in California that Agins was contrary to federal law, that Agins was unconstitutional under federal law?
Yes, we did.
May I ask you--
That it doesn't matter how you interfere with the owner's rights from the owner's standpoint.
--I understand, but you have a kind of a double-barreled claim.
That's correct.
And that's a separate form of taking.
Well, obviously we haven't gotten that far.
But you don't contend that in that situation you'd get the full value of the property, do you?
I sincerely doubt it.
Supposing the appraiser found that at the date of cancellation of the regulation the property was even more valuable than it had been when you originally wanted to build.
That it was even more valuable?
May I ask just one other question.

If the property in fact... if the use of the property was taken during that interim, I believe that is a taking, and the taking would require a trial on what just compensation is due for that period of time.
So every time you invalidate a land use regulation, you'd be entitled to some compensation for the loss of use during the period it took to litigate it?
I think it's potential, it's possible that there may be some cases where there in fact was no value lost.

Mr. Berger, the Solicitor General has suggested that, rather than implying a damage remedy directly from the Constitution or inferring one directly from the Constitution, you would have the remedy of using Section 1983.
Let me answer that in several ways, Your Honor.
Supposing it had been a federal regulatory taking.
1983 only works against state governments.
--Maybe that's why the Solicitor General thinks that that's better than applying it directly.
It's something that he's totally uninvolved in, Your Honor.
Well, it doesn't work against the state either, does it?
--You have Eleventh Amendment problems against the state.
Just municipalities, right, precisely.
Yes, we're talking here only about local government agencies.
But you haven't commented on the underlying theory of the SG's suggestion in his brief.
No.
That the Fifth Amendment is not self-executing at all.

The underlying theory of the Solicitor General, Your Honor, I candidly found insulting to this Court because it was based on expressly stating that a whole raft of opinions of this Court, including most recently U.S. versus Clarke, in which this Court said the Fifth Amendment just compensation guarantee is self-executing, are simply wrong.
Well, we just said, but we didn't hold it, because--
--That's true, you did say it.
--Where have we held that it's self-executing?
--Let me show you in Jacobs.
Against government.
In Jacobs versus United States, 290 U.S., this Court said in the holding the right to recover just compensation was guaranteed by the Constitution.
Where there's a taking.
Also--
But if the court stops the taking, then there's no compensation.
--Of course.
No, California says: We're not going to allow the taking.
I don't think they're saying that at all.
Your remedy is we will stop that taking.
That's a matter of fact.
What California says, if you take it without just compensation you've got to give it back, just as if you take--
But you can't give back what's been taken in the past.
--You cancel the regulation.
That can be, yes, that's right.
But they're two separate questions: what already occurred; when you give it back, has there still been a taking?
I don't know that we've given it back, because what it does is it returns the regulation to the entity and tells the entity, draft a new regulation.
But meanwhile you haven't had the use of your property in any event.
Exactly, and that's entirely the problem.
Well, Mr. Berger, do you think that local governments don't have authority to engage in flood control regulation?
Oh, not for a minute do I make that assertion, Justice O'Connor.
And does the church plan to rebuild on a flood plain where people have been killed?
The church can't plan to rebuild, because the ordinance won't allow it.
If you get it struck down, that's the church's plan?
If the ordinance were struck down, the church would like to be able to use the property the way it had used the property.
Well, do you think that any time a local government says, in this particular location it's subject to flooding and no one may build there, that that is a taking?
It could be.

Mr. Berger, suppose... is there anything that stands between your position and the Federal Government having to pay innumerable people nationwide some to be determined amount of compensation every time a regulation of the FCC or the FTC or any other federal agency is stricken down?
Is there anything that--
That stands between the position you're arguing here and that.
--Sure, because in my situation what we are talking about is a regulation which totally deprives the owner of property of its rightful use.
Well, how about a patented item or a designer drug of some kind, and you apply for federal approval and the regulatory process takes a long time.
That hasn't deprived you of the use of that.
Oh, yes.
I don't believe that's technically true, Your Honor.
Make that assumption, because I think there are some examples.
--Drugs is a different stories.
It's a little hard to distinguish that from your theory, frankly.
--Well, I'm sorry that Your Honor is having that trouble.
But wouldn't your argument be exactly the same if your client had bought it ten days before the regulation went in effect?
I don't think my argument would be quite as strong as if we owned it for 20 years.
You'd be making the same argument, wouldn't you?
If we bought it ten days before the regulation went into effect?
Sure, if you hadn't used it for 20 years, you bought the property ten days before and then the temporary regulation took effect.

Maybe, and we may end up arguing over the amount of damages, because if we had bought that property ten days before the regulation went into effect, after the devastating flood, I strongly suspect that the market price would have been virtually nil.
But you would be arguing there had been a temporary taking.
There still may have been a taking.
Not worth the attorney's fees.
Probably not, Your Honor.
Thank you, Mr. Berger.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
But doesn't that go beyond the ruling of the Court of Appeal, Mr. White?
--Yes, Your Honor, I do.
That's a very strange procedure.
Let me explain--
We have to decide, do we want to avoid one constitutional question in order to get to another.
--Well, first of all, the constitutional question that I'm talking about has to have been raised as a prerequisite to reaching the remedy issue.
Well, that's a different argument.
It is.
Well, it dispose the case on the basis that damages were not available.
It did, Your Honor, based on Agins.
So the case was over then.
It was over, that's correct.
Well, they're out of court.
Justice White, there was a way in which they could very easily have gotten into court in this action and preserved the issue for this Court.
But that isn't what the California Court of Appeals said here.
That's correct.
Perhaps they could have, but it didn't.
It never passed on the question of whether there was a taking.
But that's not part of the case, Mr. White.
Your Honor, I think that's correct.
Not just colorably, but fully?
--That's right.
It has to be valid.
In order to reach the remedy question.
You want us to review the federal issue that was not decided below in order not to review the federal issue that was decided below.
That's correct, because it is antecedent to reviewing the federal issue that is before the Court now.
May I ask, though, the first cause of action, last allegation, is
That's correct.
Why doesn't that allege a taking?
No, that does not, Your Honor.
Well, I understand.
--That's correct.
But they didn't do that.
And in addition to that... no, they didn't allege anything but that it denies all use, which is the barest of conclusions.
Don't we also have to look at the survey?
The survey?
Or whatever the property looks like?
Well, the question is who has the burden of presenting the facts--
It's very hard for an appellate court to try a case that hasn't been... to try an issue that hasn't been tried below.
--That's correct, Your Honor.
Why would we have to say without more that this didn't state a taking?
Why would who go to the trouble of deciding the remedy issue?
The Court of Appeals.
Because that was the only issue in front of them.
Well, it wasn't even in front of them on your theory, because there was absolutely no reason to even get to it.
--No.
You led the Court of Appeals into it?
We led the Court of Appeals into it, but the plaintiff has--
Dispose of this case on a remedy issue, forget all this business about taking.
--No, Your Honor, I don't think that's correct.
Well, that's what your motion was apparently.
Well, but--
Agins.
--But why was it the County's burden to do something beyond what was necessary--
I don't know whether it was your burden or not, but you wanted to get rid of the case on this particular federal issue, namely Agins.
--I'm sorry.
Right.
--for a taking.
Mr. White, did not the Court of Appeals, the California Court of Appeals, assume the correctness of the allegations in the complaint?
No, Your Honor.
You made a motion to strike.
But a motion to strike does not test the validity of the allegations.
Why did the Court of Appeals quote from Agins, the California Supreme Court case to the effect that there was a total taking of use?
What it said was--
Referring to the ordinance that was in the complaint.
--No, my recollection of what the Court of Appeals said was that if there is a total taking.
I don't think that's right, but you may be.
But there is only a total taking or a total denial of use that amounts to a taking if the County does not have the right to prevent that use.
Has the obligation to do it without condemnation?
--Well, the bottom line is this.
Counsel, do we have to do that to decide this case?
I think the--
Do I have to find out how wide that canyon is?
--The Court does have to decide whether the bare statement of a denial of all use states a cause of action in the face of the record that I am discussing now, the facts that are in the record.

Well, Mr. White, supposing the California Court of Appeals had expressly said: The plaintiff's complaint in this case states only that the regulation denies them all use of their property; the Appellee says this is not enough to state a claim for taking; but under our pleading law we hold that it is.
Yes, I do, Your Honor, because I think that the ultimate question of whether an adequate federal claim has been stated lies with this Court, not with the Court of Appeals in California.
May I ask you a hypothetical.
Yes.
You're talking about flood control.
I think the question... I think, Justice Powell, the question would be whether the restriction was reasonably necessary to--
Let's assume it was reasonably necessary; so that if you owned property within that area you get zero compensation, is that your construction of the Fifth Amendment?
--Your Honor, I do believe that's correct.
Let me give you another one.
Oh, of course.
Of course there would be?
Yes.
Why?
If the state wanted to make a park?
A zoning ordinance, a zoning ordinance that zones a property for park use only.
I think I may have misunderstood your question.
--And you bought the property when it was zoned, say, for residential.
Do we have the safety element involved here?
No safety element.
No safety?
Wait a minute.
--Yes.
Would there be a taking, for which compensation would be allowed?
--In your zoning case, where they had zoned it into a park, yes, Your Honor.
There would be compensation?
Well, it would be a taking for which compensation would be required if the zoning regulation remained permanent.
Well, coming back to this case, let's assume that there had never been a flood, no threat of flood.
If permitted to stand, yes, I believe that would be a taking.
It would?
Yes.
But because of the flood, that's the difference?
Yes.
Yours is limited to safety?
--Absolutely, absolutely.
Mr. White, just in case we reach the merits, do you want to say a few words about why we shouldn't imply a monetary cause of action?
Yes, Justice Scalia, I will.
It sure does, except for the interim period.
Except for the interim period, that's correct.
Now, why shouldn't we imply--
Because the interim period is nothing more than a delay inherent in the regulatory process.
--That may be, but during that delay the person has been deprived of the use of the land.
But they do in all the other cases.
What other cases?
--A delay in issuing a building permit perhaps.

Well, Mr. White, there are some horror stories out there of local governments intentionally running these things through the mill indefinitely in a jurisdiction like California, with full recognition that if they lose on one they can make a minor modification of the requirement and go again and effectively deprive people forever of any use.
Well, Justice O'Connor, I don't know of any horror stories.
Well, the Agins come pretty close, don't they?
--Well, the Agins, I don't know what happened after the Agins decision was decided.
Thank you, Mr. White.
Thank you, Your Honor.
Thank you, Mr. Berger.
